May 23, 2017: Revised to add links to digital collections site by Sarah Patton. February 17, 2016: Declassified records returned to collection and description added for 2010 release of records by Sarah Patton. February 11, 2016: Revised to add microfilm reel guide. January 13, 2016: Added microfilm reel guide pdf. January 11, 2013: Descriptions of reformatted audiovisual items updated. July 30, 2012: Revised to update encoding and add unitid by Jill Golden. October 12, 2011: Descriptions of reformatted sound recordings added. October 2010: Declassified records series added; June 10, 2010: Revised for transfer to SAL3; updated encoding to current standards. did.unittitle: United States. Civil Affairs Training School records

physdesc.extent: 59 manuscript boxes, 1 card file box, 3 sound discs

did.abstract: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, financial and personnel records, handbooks, syllabi, and instructional materials relating to the politics, governments, economies, and cultures of Japan, other areas in the Pacific, and various countries in Europe; and intelligence assessments of the war in the Pacific. Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: United States. Civil Affairs Training School, Stanford University.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Digital copies of all sound recordings are available for immediate access; digital copies also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.. To view videos, films, or digital files during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], United States. Civil Affairs Training School records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

altformavail.head: Alternative Form Available
altformavail.p: Also available on microfilm (65 reels). Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: As United States involvement in the Second World War deepened, the American military began to make contingency plans based on the likelihood of an eventual Allied victory and the need for qualified personnel to administer the occupation of liberated countries in Europe and Asia. In 1943, a training program for such personnel was established at Stanford and other universities (including Harvard and the Universities of Chicago and Michigan) under the authority of the Office of the Provost Marshal General of the United States Army. This program, known as the United States Civil Affairs Training School (or CATS) program, drew upon military personnel with experience in civil affairs or with special language abilities. The schools' curricula involved intensive courses in the languages, history, sociology, and culture of the various countries which were considered likely to be occupied by Allied forces. Particular emphasis was placed on the study of the economies of these countries, and exercises were conducted which simulated the kinds of problems likely to be encountered by occupation authorities.

The CATS program drew extensively upon the resources of the universities with which it was associated. At Stanford, university officials and faculty were recruited for the CATS program, and both the staff and the research materials of the Hoover Library played an important role in the program. Because of the need for Japanese language instructors, the CATS program also recruited among the Nisei population in the various relocation camps established after the American entry into the war. These Nisei instructors had to receive special permission from the American military in order to participate in the CATS program.
The CATS program operated at Stanford University from late 1943 until the middle of 1945. Throughout most of this time, its director was Harold Fisher, a Hoover Library official.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United States Civil Affairs Training School records consist largely of the school's academic and administrative records. There is a large amount of the course material used in classroom instruction (see ACADEMIC FILE), extensive personnel records (see ADMINISTRATIVE FILE), as well as numerous reports and intelligence estimates used for research by students (see RESEARCH MATERIAL). Much of this material gives insights into the concerns of American military planners regarding post-war occupation regimes, as well as indicating the military's perceptions of enemy countries, both as military powers and as socio-cultural formations.

There is material in the collection which discusses the origins of the school, its role within the administrative hierarchy of the Office of the Provost Marshal General, and its relations with other CATS programs (see ADMINISTRATIVE FILE, CORRESPONDENCE, and SUBJECT FILE). The question of the use of Nisei instructors is documented in the personnel records of the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assignments, correspondence, dispatches, drills, examinations, exercises, homework, invoices, lectures, memoranda, messages, notes, outlines, printed matter, reports, and syllabi, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assignments, drills, examinations, exercises, homework, lectures, outlines, and syllabi.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, dispatches, invoices, memoranda, messages, notes, reports, and printed matter.

scopecontent.p: Material relating to exercises simulating the military occupation of German and Japanese cities.

scopecontent.p: Announcements, balance sheets, budgets, bulletins, charts, clippings, contract, correspondence, directories, forms, memoranda, personnel records, printed matter, purchase orders, receipts, regulations, reports, requisitions, rules, and schedules, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

scopecontent.p: Notes and miscellany.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, notes, printed matter, and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acquisition records, bibliographies, circulation records, correspondence, filing index, holdings records, loan records, memoranda, printed matter, and reports, arranged alphabetically by physical form. See also: CARD FILE.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, and printed matter.

did.unittitle: OFFICE OF THE PROVOST MARSHAL GENERAL FILE,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The U.S. Civil Affairs Training School program was under the adminstrative supervision of the Office of the Provost Marshal General of the U.S. Army, and the Stanford school reported directly to this office. Correspondence, memoranda, organizational charts, and reports, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and memoranda.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material relating to publications produced by the U.S. Civil Affairs Training School, Stanford University. Correspondence, drafts, outlines, printed matter, and questionnaires, arranged chronologically and by degree of completion.

did.unittitle: Special Reports on Germany Prepared by Officer Students of the Civil Affairs Training School at Stanford Unversity, printed copies,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sections 1, 6, and 16 of this handbook were produced at Stanford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes responses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material, much of it orginally classified or otherwise restricted, used by students and faculty of the U.S. Civil Affairs Training School at Stanford University. Intelligence digests and estimates, reports, and translations, arranged by physical form. See also: DECLASSIFIED U.S. GOVERNMENT RECORDS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material prepared by the Office of Strategic Services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: United States Army, School of Military Government, Charlottesville, Virginia
United States Civil Affairs Holding and Staging Area, Presidio of Monterey
United States Civil Affairs Holding and Staging Area, Presidio of Monterey
United States Civil Affairs Training School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Card catalog listing holdings in the Hoover Library used by the U.S. Civil Affairs Training School, Stanford University.

did.unittitle: Photograph of class trip to Yosemite National Park,
Colonel Diller commencement speech at the School of Military Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Diller speaks to military students about to enter World War II as planners for the military government in the Far East. He begins by explaining to the audience what they can expect at the CASA (Civil Affairs Training Area) at the Presidio of Monterey in California. He says comparing Charlottesville, the location of the School of Military Government, and CASA is analogous to comparing Athens and Sparta. He also speaks about the war. Three sound discs.

dao.title: Colonel Diller commencement speech at the School of Military Government

daodesc.p: Colonel Diller commencement speech at the School of Military Government, 1945?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly security-classified records of the U.S. government, released in full or in part. Includes some interfield, unclassified government records. Arranged chronologically by date of release by Hoover, thereunder chronologically by date of creation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes preliminary drafts of the Civil Affairs Handbook on Italy, Sections 1, 3, 8, 10, 13-16 (undated); memoranda (undated); and reports produced by the Office of Strategic Services, particularly the Research and Analysis Branch (1944-1945). Available as PDF files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memoranda from the War Department, Adjutant General's Office, to Command Generals enclosing Counter Intelligence Corps Information Bulletins. Includes Bulletin No. 9 (sent 8 December 1944), Bulletin No. 10 (sent 12 February 1945), and Bulletin No. 11 (24 June 1945).
